17 
is mastoidal in shape, the shaft is flatter on its dorsal 
surface and rounder - especially at its distal end: the 
inner edge of the patellar articulation is sharp instead of being 
rounded off as in Ox and Bison, it is sharper even 
than in Ovis. All these are Ovine characters. 
<u>Tibia.<\u> the slenderness of shaft and internal malleolus, the 
roundness of the articula<s>tion<\s> surface between the inferior edges of 
the two femoral articulations are ovine characters. the internal 
groove also on its inferior surface is slightly incurved 
distally while in Bos Bison and Cervus it is straight 
<u>Metatarsal<\u>. the metatarsal in its stoutness and breadth <s>and<\s> 
especially of the condyles differs from  both Ovis and Bos 
In the shallowness of adductor groove and its absence from 
the distal third of the shaft it resembles the former 
and differs entirely from the latter animal. Its proximal 
facets are altogether Ovine. 
Hind Phalange I. differs from that of Bos by the greater flatness of its dorsal surface by the presence of a dorsal pit above the 
distal articulation and by the flat palmar area being bounded 
on wither side by a ridge it is stouter than that of sheep. 
Hind Phalange 2. The second phalange is shorter than in the 
sheep, more slender than in the ox, the  stoutness of the 
Muscular impression on the side of the proximal articulation 
that faces the corresponding phalange of the foot is 
greater than in sheep or oxen it rises into a tuberosity 
which is altogether absent from the latter, the palmar 
surface of the shaft is excavated more deeply than in 
Bos or Ovis 
Phalange 3 the articulation extends downwards nearer the 
palmar surface of the bone than in Ox or Sheep - in the
